image.altText: BRS

items.synopsis: A judge dismissed his defamation proceedings last month in a judgement that was more than 700 pages long.

title.children: Ben Roberts-Smith to appeal after losing landmark defamation case

image.altText: A sign on a building that reads: The Children's Hospital at Westmead

items.synopsis: A clinic at Westmead Children's Hospital has only seen three new patients this year and is struggling to operate in the wake of a string of staff resignations.

title.children: Review announced into delivery of gender-affirming care in NSW following Four Corners investigation

image.altText: Stephen Jones sits at a desk. He wears a suit. A large bookcase is behind him.

items.synopsis: The United Kingdom will force banks to compensate scam victims under a world-first scheme, and Australia's financial services minister now says he's considering similar rules here.

title.children: Minister indicates Australia could follow UK and force banks to reimburse scam victims

image.altText: Nick Moore

items.synopsis: The "cliff" is here or approaching for more than a million mortgage borrowers, many of whom will see their repayments jump by thousands of dollars a month.

title.children: 'You're talking about some people paying 3 or 4 per cent more on their mortgage ... overnight'

image.altText: A large brick building bearing an emblem and the name "St Joseph's Catholic College".

title.children: Well-loved year 9 girl dies weeks after catching influenza

image.altText: A woman takes a photo from a boat of an erupting volcano

items.synopsis: The criminal trial over the 2019 eruption of Whakaari White Island volcano while 42 tourists and five tour guides were in its crater has heard an allegation that its private owners decided not to pay for expert risk assessments.

title.children: Whakaari owners earned $1m a year in profit, but allegedly 'chose not to pay' for risk assessment, court hears

image.altText: An old stone building with a red dome

items.synopsis: A teen who is seeking home detention after pleading guilty to terror offences, including possessing information for a terrorist attack, shows a "sympathy towards ISIS" which "has not diminished", an Adelaide court hears.

title.children: Teenager overheard saying he 'would do something' at Anzac service next year, court told

image.altText: A mine site in bushland, as seen from above.

items.synopsis: South32 will pay almost $2.9 million after an investigation found it had been taking two Olympic pools' worth of water from Sydney's catchment per day for the last five years.

title.children: Mining company agrees to record payout after admitting to draining millions of litres from Sydney water supply

image.altText: The father and son of a Russian soldier mourn his death. They are standing by his casket, crying.

items.synopsis: Nearly 50,000 Russian men have died in the war in Ukraine, according to the first independent statistical analysis of data to learn the true human cost of Russia's invasion.

title.children: New data reveals Russia's 'hidden' death toll in Ukraine war

image.altText: A smiling elderly woman with short, white hair.

items.synopsis: The civil matter has been listed under Clare Nowland's name. The 95-year-old died in hospital earlier this year after falling and hitting her head following the alleged incident with a police officer.

title.children: Family of great-grandmother who died after allegedly being tasered by police sues NSW

image.altText: Angus Beaumont who was stabbed to death in a Redcliffe park, smiling and wearing a beanie

items.synopsis: Angus Beaumont died after he was stabbed in the chest in Redcliffe in March 2020.

title.children: Teenage killers of Queensland 15-year-old suffered 'miscarriage of justice' and will be retried, court rules

image.altText: Chau Van Kham, centre, pictured with his wife Trang and Chris Bowen.

items.synopsis: Vietnam frees Australian man Chau Van Kham who was detained in 2019 and sentenced to 12 years in prison on terrorism charges.

title.children: 'Absolutely emotional': Sydney man freed from Vietnam prison and returned to Australia

image.altText: A dead crocodile is laid out onto a table with its mouth being held open by a man

items.synopsis: The saltwater crocodile involved in an attack at Wangi Falls in the Northern Territory has been killed, while the 67-year-old victim remains in hospital in Darwin.

title.children: 'We'll do the skull and gift it to him': Crocodile skull offered to attack victim

image.altText: Two penguins stand on rocks in a paddling pool

items.synopsis: Fiordland penguins rarely make landfall on the Australian continent so a recent influx has a researcher concerned about tough feeding conditions.

title.children: Rare penguins' Aussie arrival not a good sign, researcher says

image.altText: Craig Kelly addresses a group of journalists.

items.synopsis: A Federal Court judge criticises the Australian Electoral Commission's conduct in a dispute with former federal MP Craig Kelly about his 2022 election campaign posters.

title.children: 'The theft was rife': Craig Kelly in court over federal campaign poster dispute

image.altText: Two men celebrate after winning a State of Origin match

items.synopsis: Josh Reynolds's Origin career only lasted four games but his time in the sky-blue jersey explains a key difference between New South Wales and Queensland, writes Nick Campton.

title.children: The Josh Reynolds factor and why the Blues still don't get Origin like Queenslanders do

image.altText: Woman in jeans, maroon top and white sneakers sitting down on stairs.

items.synopsis: A woman is seeking compensation from the Tasmanian government and a netball association over the sexual abuse she suffered at the hands of notorious paedophile nurse James Geoffrey Griffin.

title.children: Sexual abuse survivor suing government, sporting organisation, after abuse by paedophile nurse

image.altText: A woman looking at the camera with her face blurred.

items.synopsis: A magistrate tells the court the Molong man poses an "unacceptable" risk despite being incapacitated in intensive care.

title.children: Magistrate refuses bail for NSW man charged with murdering ex-wife in car crash

image.altText: aerial picture of remote roadhouse with 4WDs parked out front

items.synopsis: After nearly two decades serving up their famous enormous burgers, rescuing dozens of stranded motorists and seeing a three-fold increase in traffic, the owners of one of Australia's most remote roadhouses have handed over the keys.

title.children: End of an era as remote roadhouse changes hands for first time in 18 years

image.altText: Anthony Albanese and German Chancellor Scholz review the troops in Berlin

items.synopsis: Australia has agreed to join the German-led Climate Club. What is the club and will it make any difference to the nation's climate goals?

title.children: Why has Australia signed up to Germany's Climate Club and what difference will it make?

image.altText: A woman with short blonde hair, wearing a pinstripe jacket, sits in the kitchen of a house.

items.synopsis: Research has shown that renters in Australia could be more likely to face physical and mental health problems than owners.

title.children: It took Shay almost a month to find a rental. Now it might be making her sick

image.altText: a drone shot of a town nestled between red rock ranges

items.synopsis: Police in Kununurra faced significant public unrest over the weekend, with rocks thrown at officers during the incident.

title.children: Kimberley police pushed to limit by 12-hour brawl involving more than 80 people

image.altText: A man with brown hair wearing a denim jacket smiles

items.synopsis: A cluster of drowning deaths in the Canberra region reveal a lack of danger awareness around rivers, Coroner Paula Russell says.

title.children: Four ACT riverside outings turned tragic within 16 months. A coroner says the victims didn't know the dangers

image.altText: Madonna, sitting during an awards show, looks in the distance as blue light dims the hall.

items.synopsis: The 64-year-old singer has postponed her entire North American tour and is now focusing on "getting stronger".

title.children: Madonna makes first public statement after spending multiple days in intensive care

image.altText: City office-workers and passers-by watch the ASX board in Sydney

items.synopsis: The Australian share market begins its day sharply higher as Wall Street recovers from its three-day losing streak, ahead of a US inflation report which will determine whether the US Federal Reserve lifts interest rates again this month. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX rebounds from four-day losing streak

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It was a strong finish for the Australian share market, with the ASX 200 closing 1.5% higher at 7,109 points. In fact, this was the market's biggest single-day gain since January 4, with industrials, real estate and mining stocks driving the gains. However, before today, the local bourse had fallen sharply (for four straight sessions). So it has essentially recovered back to where it was last Friday, after today's solid gains. Almost every stock on ASX 200 finished higher Bellevue Gold (+15.2%), Capricorn Metals (+8.1%), Lake Resources (+7.1%) and De Grey Mining (+5.8%) rising sharply. The best performer, by far, was Megaport (+33.8%) after the tech business upgraded its earnings guidance for the 2022-23 financial year, and told investors that it's expecting an even better result in the year ahead. On the flip side, the worst performers were Johns Lyng Group (-1.9%), Imugene (-1.1%) and Amcor (-1.1%). By 4:30pm AEST, the Australian dollar had risen 0.2% to 66.85 US cents. This was partly because the US dollar index fell to a two-month low after Federal Reserve officials signalled that the central bank was nearing the end of its tightening cycle. Several Fed officials said on Monday (local time) the US central bank will likely need to raise interest rates further to bring down inflation but the end to its current monetary policy tightening cycle is getting close. Interest rate expectations have been a key driver of the US dollar since the Fed began its tightening cycle last year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian share market records best trading day since January

children.content: It was a strong finish for the Australian share market, with the
ASX 200 closing 1.5% higher at 7,109 points.
In fact, this was the market's biggest single-day gain since January 4, with industrials, real estate and mining stocks driving the gains.
However, before today, the local bourse had fallen sharply (for four straight sessions).
So it has essentially recovered back to where it was last Friday, after today's solid gains.
Almost every stock on ASX 200 finished higher Bellevue Gold (+15.2%), Capricorn Metals (+8.1%), Lake Resources (+7.1%) and De Grey Mining (+5.8%) rising sharply.

The best performer, by far, was Megaport (+33.8%) after the tech business upgraded its earnings guidance for the 2022-23 financial year, and told investors that it's expecting an even better result in the year ahead.
On the flip side, the worst performers were Johns Lyng Group (-1.9%), Imugene (-1.1%) and Amcor (-1.1%).
By 4:30pm AEST, the Australian dollar had risen 0.2% to
66.85 US cents.
This was partly because the US dollar index fell to a two-month low after Federal Reserve officials signalled that the central bank was nearing the end of its tightening cycle.

Several Fed officials said on Monday (local time) the US central bank will likely need to raise interest rates further to bring down inflation but the end to its current monetary policy tightening cycle is getting close.
Interest rate expectations have been a key driver of the US dollar since the Fed began its tightening cycle last year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Shares of Chinese property developers rose on Tuesday after regulators extended some policies in a rescue package introduced in November to shore up liquidity in the embattled sector. Analysts said while the extended policy could ease the short-term financial pressure on property developers and ensure their home project completions, new measures would be needed to tackle the cash crunch in the sector. The sector has been hit by many company defaults amid a debt crisis since mid-2021, triggered by non-repayments of China Evergrande Group 3333.HK, the world's most indebted property developer. The central bank on Monday said it would give developers an extra 12 months to repay loans due this year, with many private firms still struggling to access new capital despite policymakers' aggressive support measures. Markets expect more stimulus to be rolled out soon. Last November, the People's Bank of China (PBOC) put in place 16 measures to support the cash-strapped sector, including loan repayment extensions, to ease a deepening liquidity crisis. On Monday, the PBOC said it would allow loans due this year to be repaid before the end of 2024. Separately, it said the risk classifications of loans issued to support the delivery of unfinished projects before the end of 2024 will not be downgraded during their loan terms. Financial firm Nomura said the "band-aid-style" policy support on Monday is unlikely to revive property sales, which have been weak for months, as it does little to restore home buyers' confidence. By 3:30pm AEST, the Hang Seng index had jumped 1.3% to 18,725 points, while the Shanghai Composite was up 0.3% to 3,214. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Mainland Properties Index gained 1.8%. Sunac China, Logan Group and KWG Group, listed in Hong Kong were, among the top gainers, rising 4 - 5%. - Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: China property shares rise on financial support policy

children.content: Shares of Chinese property developers rose on Tuesday after regulators extended some policies in a rescue package introduced in November to shore up liquidity in the embattled sector.

Analysts said while the extended policy could ease the short-term financial pressure on property developers and ensure their home project completions, new measures would be needed to tackle the cash crunch in the sector.
The sector has been hit by many company defaults amid a debt crisis since mid-2021, triggered by non-repayments of China Evergrande Group 3333.HK, the world's most indebted property developer.

The central bank on Monday said it would give developers an extra 12 months to repay loans due this year, with many private firms still struggling to access new capital despite policymakers' aggressive support measures.
Markets expect more stimulus to be rolled out soon.
Last November, the People's Bank of China (PBOC) put in place 16 measures to support the cash-strapped sector, including loan repayment extensions, to ease a deepening liquidity crisis.
On Monday, the PBOC said it would allow loans due this year to be repaid before the end of 2024.
Separately, it said the risk classifications of loans issued to support the delivery of unfinished projects before the end of 2024 will not be downgraded during their loan terms.
Financial firm Nomura said the "band-aid-style" policy support on Monday is unlikely to revive property sales, which have been weak for months, as it does little to restore home buyers' confidence.
By 3:30pm AEST, the Hang Seng index had jumped 1.3% to 18,725 points, while the Shanghai Composite was up 0.3% to 3,214.
Hong Kong's Hang Seng Mainland Properties Index
gained 1.8%.
Sunac China, Logan Group and KWG Group, listed in Hong Kong were, among the top gainers, rising 4 - 5%.
- Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Weak economic data from our largest trading partner China has led to a big fall in iron ore prices (Australia's biggest export to China). The spot price for the steelmaking material (62% iron) dropped to just over $US105 / tonne, its lowest level since June 1. Here's what Commonwealth Bank commodities analyst Vivek Dhar wrote in his latest note to clients: "The demand concerns in China were highlighted by Rio Tinto’s chairman Dominic Barton, when he noted ‘there is a big real estate issue” in China. His comments underscore a deteriorating property sector that accounts for 35 - 40% of China’s steel demand. "A number of property related indicators have turned south. New home price growth has begun to slow after peaking in March 2023. Property investment and property sales (in square metres) has started to contract sharply, falling 22%/yr and 20%/yr respectively in May. "The most relevant indicator for steel demand and therefore the most important for iron ore prices is the drop off in China’s newly constructed floor space. "This reflects the start of the construction process and where steel is mostly used. After dropping ~39%/yr in 2022, China’s newly constructed floor space has declined another ~23%/yr in the first five months of 2023." He also said the surprise slowdown in China’s consumer price index (CPI) to 0% in June highlights broader concerns for China’s economy: "These concerns only increase the likelihood of policy support. And with Politburo’s semi annual economic conference due later this month, we expect policymakers will announce some support for the Chinese economy. "The composition of the policy support will be crucial. Our expectation is that any policy support will be limited, particularly with China only targeting economic growth of 5% this year after growing only 3% in 2022. "Since the early 1970s, China’s economy has lifted at least 7.5% after growing 3% or less the preceding year. "Solving the issues of the property sector will be tricky given confidence and demand are so subdued following the fallout from property developer defaults and falling new home prices through 2022. "As a result we think any support for the property sector will need to be longer and stronger than previous policies. Any stabilisation will therefore be more realistically realised next year."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Iron ore prices drop to five-week low

children.content: Weak economic data from our largest trading partner China has led to a big fall in iron ore prices (Australia's biggest export to China).
The spot price for the steelmaking material (62% iron) dropped to just over $US105 / tonne, its lowest level since June 1.
Here's what Commonwealth Bank commodities analyst Vivek Dhar wrote in his latest note to clients:

"The demand concerns in China were highlighted by Rio Tinto’s chairman Dominic Barton, when he noted ‘there is a big real estate issue” in China. His comments underscore a deteriorating property sector that accounts for 35 - 40% of China’s steel demand.

"A number of property related indicators have turned south. New home price growth has begun to slow after peaking in March 2023. Property investment and property sales (in square metres) has started to contract sharply, falling 22%/yr and 20%/yr respectively in May.
"The most relevant indicator for steel demand and therefore the most important for iron ore prices is the drop off in China’s newly constructed floor space.

"This reflects the start of the construction process and where steel is mostly used. After dropping ~39%/yr in 2022, China’s newly constructed floor space has declined another ~23%/yr in the first five months of 2023."
He also said the surprise slowdown in China’s consumer price index (CPI) to 0% in June highlights broader concerns for China’s economy:

"These concerns only increase the likelihood of policy support. And with Politburo’s semi annual economic conference due later this month, we expect policymakers will announce some support for the Chinese economy.

"The composition of the policy support will be crucial. Our expectation is that any policy support will be limited, particularly with China only targeting economic growth of 5% this year after growing only 3% in 2022.
"Since the early 1970s, China’s economy has lifted at least 7.5% after growing 3% or less the preceding year.
"Solving the issues of the property sector will be tricky given confidence and demand are so subdued following the fallout from property developer defaults and falling new home prices through 2022.
"As a result we think any support for the property sector will need to be longer and stronger than previous policies. Any stabilisation will therefore be more realistically realised next year."

image.altText: a photo of a man sitting at a small table in a caravan

items.synopsis: Residents are wondering where they will go, after they were asked to leave their homes at a Bendigo caravan park with just two weeks' notice.

title.children: Permanent residents of caravan park given weeks to find new homes after developer buys property

image.altText: Boxes of feta cheese on the production line with "Protected Designation of Origin" written on the labels.

items.synopsis: The future of Australian producers using terms like prosecco and feta hangs in the balance as trade talks with the European Union over a deal that could be worth $100 billion reach a critical moment.

title.children: Australia could keep prosecco and feta and walk away from EU trade talks

image.altText: A tennis player with hands on hips argues with a chair umpire at Wimbledon.

items.synopsis: Tears, injuries, upsets and a harsh interpretation of the laws of tennis cause controversy at The All England Club, while Novak Djokovic just keeps on winning.

title.children: 'It's the wrong decision': Russian teen lashes Wimbledon umpire over point penalty controversy
